With the aim of studying the effect of support structure and preparation method on the hydrogenation performance of Ni-based catalysts. Hollow mesoporous silica spheres (hw-mSiO2) containing tiny Ni nanoparticles highly dispersed on the inner surface (Ni@hw-mSiO2) were synthesized by using carbon sphere as template with four continuous procedures, containing Ni deposition, silica shell coating, calcination and reduction. As demonstrated by SEM and TEM, the hollow structure was successfully obtained after calcination and the active Ni species was highly dispersed inside the porous silica shell, which is much smaller than the Ni-based catalysts prepared by a conventional impregnation method using hw-mSiO2 (Ni/hw-mSiO2) or commercial SiO2 (Ni/mSiO2) as supports. TPR and H2-chemisorption results revealed the existence of strong metal-interaction and more hydrogenation sites in Ni@hw-mSiO2. Therefore, Ni@hw-mSiO2 catalyst achieved an excellent catalytic activity and stability in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline into 1–4-tetrahydroquinoline (py-THQ), due to the more dispersed Ni species, strong metal-support interaction and confinement effect of porous silica shell. Graphical abstract A novel yolk-shell Ni@hw-mSiO2 catalyst showed outstanding activity and stability in quinoline hydrogenation into 1–4-tetrahydroquinoline Image, graphical abstract Keywords Quinoline hydrogenation Hollow silica sphere Ni dispersion Confinement effect Stability Introduction The selective hydrogenation of quinoline and its derivatives is a high atom efficient and convenient route to produce 1–4-tetrahydroquinolines (py-THQ), which is an important synthetic intermediate for pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and other applications [1–3]. Large number of homogeneous catalysts based on Ru [4], Rh [5], Au [6] and Ir [7] have been studied in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline, but the difficulties in their separation and recovery also affected the application of such catalysts. Therefore, heterogeneous catalysts play an important role in this transformation [8]. However, most of the high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for quinoline hydrogenation are also noble metal, including Pt [9], Ru [10], Pd [11,12] and Au [13] based catalysts. For example, Mao and co-workers prepared a Pd@CNTs catalyst by confining Pd nanoparticles into the channels of CNTs. The as-prepared catalyst showed exceptional catalytic activity and selectivity in atmospheric hydrogenation of quinoline [14]. Although noble metal catalysts showed excellent activity in quinoline hydrogenation, the scarcity and high cost of such precious metals limited their practical applications. The development of cheap and earth abundant non-noble metal-based catalysts is of high importance for the selective hydrogenation of quinoline and its derivatives, as well as in many other applications [15]. Recently, Ni-based catalysts have been widely used in many catalytic transformations especially as catalyst in hydrogenation due to their reasonable price, availability and activity [16–20]. For example, Lv and co-workers designed a confined Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst by an ammonia evaporation hydrothermal method and showed good activity in guaiacol hydrogenation [21]. However, the Ni metal nanoparticles constructed from high temperature pyrolysis often induce the metal aggregation and then lead to the reduction of metal dispersion and active sites, further affecting the performance of the catalyst [22–24]. At the meanwhile, the leaching of the active Ni during reaction also decreased the stability of the Ni based catalysts [25–27]. To prevent these drawbacks, several methods, such as promoter addition and in-situ generation of Ni nanoparticles, have been studied [28–30]. In addition, the design of hierarchical structure Ni-based catalyst is also an efficient way to improve the catalytic performance [31]. Nowadays, the synthesis of metal nanoparticles encapsulated inside hollow porous spheres (HPS) has received much attention because this kind of material has several advantages, such as a long life, high activity and stability in harsh reaction conditions [32]. Two general methods have been used for the loading of a metal into HPS. One is to synthesize the HPS first and then introduce the metal into the HPS. Another is to deposit the metal on the surface of template, cover the surface with corresponding shell and then remove the template, leaving the metal inside the HPS. Silica [33], titania [34], carbon [35] and alumina [36] have been synthesized as HPS and noble metal nanoparticles such as Pd [37], Rh [38], Au [36] and Ag [39] have been successfully encapsulated inside them. As expected, the obtained yolk-shell catalysts exhibited better activity than the traditional supported catalysts in corresponding reactions. In addition, Ni-based yolk-shell catalysts were also prepared as effective catalysts with superior ability to avoid Ni sintering and carbon resistance. For example, Lu et al. fabricated the Ni@HSS catalyst with the promotion of VOx, which exhibited high stability for the dry reforming of methane reaction [40]. However, few pieces of literature have reported the use of Ni-based yolk-shell catalyst in the hydrogenation of organic unsaturated compounds, and the effect of preparation method on their catalytic activity had not been studied. In our previous work, a core-shell Fe3O4@nSiO2@NiPd–PVP@mSiO2 catalyst was prepared and the highly-dispersed Ni particles sandwiched between two slilica shells displayed superb catalytic activity in cinnamic acid hydrogenation [41]. As a continuous work to develop high efficiency Ni-based catalysts based on the confinement effect [42]. A yolk-shell Ni@hw-mSiO2 catalyst was designed and prepared using nano carbon sphere as template and applied in quinoline hydrogenation. For comparison, Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2 prepared by an impregnation method were also used in this transformation. Interestingly, Ni@hw-mSiO2 showed not only better Ni dispersion, but also good catalytic stability in quinoline hydrogenation. Hence, a series of characterization were performed to demonstrate the effect of preparation method and support structure on the catalytic performance. Experimental Materials Unless otherwise stated, all reagents were analytical or technical grades purchased from Baoding Huaxin Reagent and Apparatus Co. Ltd and were used without further purification. Fumed silica (mSiO2) was obtained from Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd. Deionized water was used in all the experiments where water was used. The detailed fabrication process of Ni@hw-mSiO2 Synthesis of carbon spheres: carbon spheres were synthesized as templates by a hydrothermal method. First, 7.20 g glucose was dissolved in 80 mL water by sonication and then transferred to 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave for heat treatment at 180 °C for 10 h under autogenous pressure. The obtained solid samples were washed several times with water, filtered and separated, and dried at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain carbon spheres. Synthesis of C@Ni: typically, carbon sphere (0.50 g) and Ni(NO3)2•6H2O (0.28 g) were dispersed and dissolved respectively in 50 mL water by sonication and then stirred for 20 min at 80 °C. A sodium hydroxide solution (1 mol L−1) was added to this solution until pH = 11 while stirring. The mixture was then stirred and refluxed at 80 °C for 5 h. After cooling, the product was the filtered and washed repeatedly using water. Synthesis of Ni@hw-mSiO2: 0.40 g C@Ni composites were dispersed in 80 mL water and sonicated for 20 min, denoted as solution A. At the meanwhile, 0.35 g cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) was dissolved in 60 mL water and stirred at room temperature for 5 min. After the addition of 2.5 mL ammonia solution (1 mol•L−1), the obtained mixture was denoted as solution B. Solution B was added dropwise into solution A and stirred for another 30 min. Then, 0.6 mL tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added drop by drop and stirred for 12 h. Finally, the resulting solid was filtered and calcined at 673 K for 4 h using a heating ramp of 2 K•min−1 in a muffle furnace and reduced at 723 K for 2 h under H2. As comparison, Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2 was prepared using hw-mSiO2 and the fumed silica (mSiO2) as support by an impregnation method. The hw-mSiO2 was prepared under the same procedure as Ni/hw-mSiO2 except the Ni deposition on carbon sphere. Catalyst activity test The performance of prepared catalyst was carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer and an electric heating system. The catalyst (0.16 g), quinoline (1 mL) and ethanol (30 mL) were successively added into the reactor and the autoclave was filled with H2 three times followed by evacuation, pressurized with H2 to 2 MPa and heated to 100 °C for 2 h. When the reaction was completed, the reaction mixtures were analyzed by Agilent 7820 A gas chromatography and the structures of the products were identified by gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy (GC-MS) on a Thermofisher 1300+ISQ LT spectrometer. Catalyst characterization Ni content of the prepared catalysts was measured by the inductively coupled plasma microscopy (ICP) on an Agilent 7700 spectrometer. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume were identified on a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 apparatus surface area and pore analyzer. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed on a Bruker D8 diffractometer using a Cu Ka radiation source. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was performed on a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN microscope. The samples were dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonication and loaded on a copper grid for analysis. The particle size distributions and the mean size of the catalysts are derived by measuring 100 randomly distributed Ni particles. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed on a FEI Nova 600 instrument. Temperature-programmed reduction, H2-chemisorption and H2 temperature-programmed desorption were performed using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. The Ni dispersion was calculated based on the absorbed H2 volume. Thermogravimetric Analysis was performed on a NETZSCH STA449F3-QMS403D instrument under an air flow from 25–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 K min−1. Results and discussion The schematic sketch of the synthetic process of Ni@hw-mSiO2 is displayed in Fig. 1 a. Carbon spheres were made by a classical route and used as template for the preparation of Ni@hw-mSiO2. Ni nanoparticles were deposited on the surface of carbon spheres by using a co-precipitation method in aqueous solution. The coverage of C@Ni was performed with SiO2 using tetraethoxy orthosilicate (TEOS) as silica source. The Ni nanoparticles were sandwiched between carbon template and silica shell and anchored on the inner surface of hw-mSiO2. The confinement effect could make the Ni nanoparticles highly-dispersed and generate strong interaction with silica during calcination, which is benefit for the formation of small Ni particles. This synthetic method is believed to be environmental friendly and have good economics due to nonuse of large amounts of expensive organic solvents and surfactants. In addition, compared with the yolk-shell catalysts prepared by the impregnation method, this process also provides an efficient way to make the Ni species more dispersed on the inner surface of support. The calcination temperature of C@Ni@SiO2 precursor was determined by TGA characterization. As shown in Fig. S1, the thermal profile of C@Ni@SiO2 exhibited a two-step weight loss process with the first at a temperature below 110 °C corresponding to loss of the adsorbed water. The main weight loss occurred in the temperature range of 200–400 °C, which was corresponded to the decomposition of carbon sphere template in C@Ni@SiO2. The total weight loss of the second step was 64.9%, which was close to the weight percentage of carbon template in C@Ni@SiO2 (66.5 %), indicating the complete decomposition of carbon template. Therefore, 400 °C was selected as the calcination temperature because the carbon template could be completely removed after calcination. In addition, TGA result of Ni@hw-mSiO2 further indicated the totally removal of the carbon template, as no significant weight loss occurred when the temperature was higher than 100 °C. (Fig. S1). In order to study whether structure collapse occurred during calcination, the morphologies of different samples during preparation are displayed in Fig. 1b–e. The average diameter of the carbon spheres is 500 nm (Fig. 1b and c). As Ni@hw-mSiO2 were made with a prior step involving the deposition of Ni particles and silica coating. The C@Ni@SiO2, which made from the silica coating had a wall thickness of ca. 50 nm and the total diameter of this sample is about 590 nm (Fig. 1d). Following the removal of carbon template by heating at 400 °C in air, the resulting Ni@hw-mSiO2 took the shape of the template and had an average diameter of 300 nm. This phenomenon may attribute to the removal of carbon template and formation of cavity structure in Ni@hw-mSiO2, thus diminished the shape of obtained hollow sphere. In addition, the hollow structure could be observed in the obtained samples from the breakage of one special sphere (Fig. 1e). Therefore, it could be concluded that the structure collapse was not happened during calcination. TEM images together with particle size distributions of the Ni@hw-mSiO2, Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The hollow structure of Ni@hw-mSiO2 could be observed in panoramic picture (Fig. S2), which is in line with the SEM results. As can be seen from Fig. 2a, with the uniform distributed Ni particles, the size of the Ni particles in Ni@hw-mSiO2 were extraordinarily small than the other two catalysts. The encapsulated Ni nanoparticles are well dispersed inside the hollow silica spheres and no Ni nanoparticles are found on the outside of silica shell using this procedure. The particle size distribution histogram indicates that the Ni nanoparticles present a small and narrow distribution of size from 2.5 to 6.5 nm with average particle size of 4.4 nm. STEM analysis was also performed to further study the morphology of Ni@hw-mSiO2. It appears that Ni nanoparticles are inside the hollow silica spheres. The EDX elemental analysis and EDX line mapping of Ni@hw-mSiO2 shows the distribution of Ni, Si and O in the catalyst structure, with the core rich in Ni and the shell rich in Si and O, demonstrating the existence of the Ni nanoparticles inside the silica spheres (Fig. 3 ) [43]. Considering the Ni/hw-mSiO2 catalyst, it is clear that most of Ni nanoparticles were load inside the silica sphere support, while others aggregated on the outside of hw-mSiO2. Ni nanoparticles of Ni/hw-mSiO2 have a broad size distribution and the mean size is 6.4 nm (Fig. 2d). As for Ni/mSiO2, Ni nanoparticles distributed on the surface of support and the size distribution is more broad from 7 to 14 nm (Fig. 2 e and f). The average particle size is around 9 nm, which is generally larger than Ni@hw-mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the three catalysts suggest that the silica shell had a pore structure of type I/IV, containing both micropores and mesopores (Fig. S3) [35]. This porosity was also proved by the pore size distribution plots, as the nitrogen desorption of pore diameter is major in the range of 2–50 nm, indicating the mesoporous structure is dominant in the three catalysts. Table 1 shows the specific surface area and pore volume values of Ni@hw-mSiO2, Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2. For comparison, the corresponding values of hw-mSiO2 and mSiO2 were also measured (not shown in Table 1). The hw-mSiO2 has a specific surface area of 829 m2 g−1 and pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g−1. In contrast, the same values of mSiO2 are 250 m2 g−1 and 0.27 cm3 g−1, respectively. These values for Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2 were both decreased due to the occupying of channels by the introduction of Ni nanoparticles. However, the surface area of Ni@hw-mSiO2 has a slightly increase to 873 m2 g−1 with an almost unchanged pore volume (0.46 cm3 g−1), implying that the encapsulated tiny Ni nanoparticles did not alter the porosity of the silica shell in Ni@hw-mSiO2 and the high dispersed Ni particles on the inner surface resulted the slightly increase of surface area. In addition, hydrogen plus chemisorption experimental data was also collected and shown in Table 1. Ni@hw-mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2 both showed higher values of H2-chemisorption and Ni dispersion than Ni/mSiO2, and Ni@hw-mSiO2 exhibited the largest values among the three catalysts. These results indicate that the structure and preparation method of Ni@hw-mSiO2 are more conductive to the dispersion of the active Ni species. The textural property of Ni@hw-mSiO2 can facilitate the diffusion of the reactants to the Ni active site surface in the cavity and avoid the loss of the Ni species during reaction [44]. The powder XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . As can be seen, all samples exhibit a broad diffraction peak at the range from 15 to 30 o, which can be attributed to the amorphous SiO2 [45]. All the three catalysts after calcination show the FCC-NiO phase (JCPDS No. 78–0429), with the typical reflection peaks at 2θ = 37.2, 43.3 and 62.9 °, attributed to the (111), (200) and (220) planes [46]. Fig. 4B displays the XRD spectra of the three catalysts after reduction, which show visible different peak patterns. The pattern of Ni/mSiO2 exhibits obvious peaks at 2θ = 44.3, 51.8 and 76.4 °, together with the disappearance of the peaks of NiO, indicating the full reduction of Ni in this sample [47]. In contrast, the peaks of the other two samples are much wider and smaller, suggesting that the crystal size of Ni should be smaller in them (especially for Ni@hw-mSiO2) [48]. Therefore, by considering the previous reports [42], the more dispersed Ni species in Ni@hw-mSiO2 may generate more strong interaction between metal and support, thus the agglomeration of Ni species is inhibited during reduction. The interaction between nickel and support is investigated by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 5 , Ni/mSiO2 presents one main reduction peak between 250 and 350 °C, which was caused by the reduction of the bulk NiO or NiO weakly interacted with the silica support [49]. At the meanwhile, Ni/hw-mSiO2 also shows an obvious reduction peak at 316 °C together with a shoulder reduction peak centered at 396 °C. As the higher reduction temperature illustrates the stronger metal support interaction [50], therefore, this result indicates the existence of a little amount Ni nanoparticles have stronger interaction with support in Ni/hw-mSiO2. In contrast, Ni@hw-mSiO2 shows distinct type of reduction peaks, as one main broad peak centered around 451 °C appeared in this sample, which is attributed to stronger interaction between NiO and the support. The strong metal support interaction could prevent the agglomeration of the small Ni nanoparticles during reduction, thus generate more active site for hydrogenation. Additionally, a lower reduction peak (278 °C) is also found in Ni@hw-mSiO2, which may be attributed to some small Ni nanoparticles have weaker interaction with support. In order to further study the interaction between Ni and support, XPS measurements were performed on the reduced Ni@hw-mSiO2, Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2. As shown in Fig. 6 , the Ni 2p3/2 presented two valence states. As previously reported, the binding energies of metallic Ni and NiO are around 852 and 855 eV [42]. Therefore, the peaks at about 852.6–852.9 eV could be attributed to metallic Ni and the peaks in the range of 855.2–856.1 eV demonstrated the presence of NiO in the three samples. The existence of NiO may be caused by the partly oxidation of metallic Ni during the sample transfer and settlement before XPS test. Notably, the binding energies of metallic and NiO in Ni@hw-mSiO2 were higher than that of Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2, indicating the stronger metal-support interaction in Ni@hw-mSiO2 [47]. Combined with TEM and TPR results, we can demonstrate that the more dispersed Ni nanoparticles in Ni@hw-mSiO2 could enhance the interaction between Ni and SiO2 support, which can effectively suppress the agglomeration and loss of active Ni, thus improve the hydrogenation performance of Ni@hw-mSiO2. Fig. S4 shows the H2-TPD profiles of Ni@hw-mSiO2, Ni/hw-mSiO2 and Ni/mSiO2, with all the profiles demonstrating two main desorption peaks. One is in the range of 50–200 °C and the other is in a higher rang of 300–450 °C. This indicates two types of hydrogenation active sites in these catalysts [51]. Compared with Ni/mSiO2, the integrated area of the low temperature peak in Ni@hw-mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2 decreased, while the high temperature peak increased. As previously reported, the low temperature desorption peak is related to the H2 desorption from free metal surface of weak hydrogenation sites, and the latter is related to the H2 desorption from the strong hydrogenation sites [52]. Therefore, it could be concluded that with the decrease in Ni particle size and increase in Ni dispersion, the amount of the relative weak hydrogenation sites decreased and that of strong hydrogenation sites increased in Ni@hw-mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2. Moreover, for Ni@hw-mSiO2, the high temperature peak is larger than that of Ni/hw-mSiO2, indicating more strong hydrogenation sites existed in this catalyst. The catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts was studied in the hydrogenation of quinoline, and the results are shown in Table 2 . As can be seen, the conversion of quinoline was 23.7% over Ni/mSiO2, indicating its low activity toward hydrogenation. However, the conversion of quinoline increased to 33.9% over Ni/hw-mSiO2, lower than our initial expectation for the introduction of hollow structure supports. In contrast, the conversion was 98.9% over Ni@hw-mSiO2, which can be attributed to the better dispersion of Ni nanoparticles in the silica cavity and the appropriate porous structure of silica shell. The conversion of quinoline versus metallic Ni active sites (calculated based on H2-chemisorption results) is shown in Fig. 7 . It is distinct that the quinoline conversion over the three catalysts increased with the increase of Ni active sites. This explained the varied activity of the three catalysts with similar Ni content on quinoline hydrogenation: higher Ni dispersion resulted in smaller Ni nanoparticles and more metallic Ni active sites in Ni@hw-mSiO2, thus led to higher hydrogenation activity of Ni@hw-mSiO2. Notably, the selectivity for 1–4-tetrahydroquinoline was all over 95% for these three catalysts. This may be due to the abundant –OH groups on the surface of SiO2, which are benefit for adsorption of quinoline by the hydrogen bonding between –OH and N atom in quinoline molecular [53]. In the stability tests of the three catalysts (Fig. 8 ), the conversion decreased obviously only after 4 cycles over Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2 with the lower initial activity, whereas Ni@hw-mSiO2 could maintain high activity after 6 cycles with the conversion of quinoline over 85%, indicating the better stability of Ni@hw-mSiO2. The XRD patterns of the used catalysts were basically consistent with the fresh samples, indicating there was no obvious change in diffraction of the main crystal phase and the oxidation of Ni was not happened during reaction (Fig. S5). In addition, the ICP results of the used Ni@hw-mSiO2 showed that the Ni loading only dropped from 12.37 to 12.07% after 6 cycles (Table S1). The slow rate of Ni loss may be one reason to explain the better stability of Ni@hw-mSiO2, which attributed to the stronger metal-support interaction and the confinement effect of mSiO2 cavity. The inconspicuous change in Ni content of fresh and used catalysts also indicated the heterogenous catalytic process in this work. Moreover, as shown in Table S2, Ni@hw-mSiO2 exhibited better catalytic performance than the most reported non-noble metal catalysts in the quinoline hydrogenation and even comparable to most reported noble metal catalysts, indicating the potential application of such kind of Ni-based catalyst. Conclusions In this work, a Ni-based catalyst with hollow silica spheres containing highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles on the inner surface (Ni@hw-SiO2) was synthesized and tested in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline. In comparison to Ni/mSiO2 and Ni/hw-mSiO2, the Ni@hw-mSiO2 catalyst showed excellent activity and stability, affording 98.9% quinoline conversion and 97.1% py-THQ selectivity under the selected reaction conditions. The unique preparation method was believed to be the decisive factor for its good catalytic performance. On the one hand, the existence of sandwiched structure during preparation promoted the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles on silica shell. After calcination, a strong interaction between Ni and support could be generated. On the other hand, owing to the strong metal-support interaction and hierarchical structure, the stability of the Ni species could be maintained during reaction. Therefore, the small Ni nanoparticles and strong metal-support interactions existed in Ni@hw-mSiO2 resulted in its better catalytic performance. This work provides a fundamental understanding on how to fabricate the active sites in yolk-shell structure material and then enhance the activity in corresponding reactions, which is referential for the rational design of efficient catalysts for utilization. coredata.dc:description: With the aim of studying the effect of support structure and preparation method on the hydrogenation performance of Ni-based catalysts. Hollow mesoporous silica spheres (hw-mSiO2) containing tiny Ni nanoparticles highly dispersed on the inner surface (Ni@hw-mSiO2) were synthesized by using carbon sphere as template with four continuous procedures, containing Ni deposition, silica shell coating, calcination and reduction. As demonstrated by SEM and TEM, the hollow structure was successfully obtained after calcination and the active Ni species was highly dispersed inside the porous silica shell, which is much smaller than the Ni-based catalysts prepared by a conventional impregnation method using hw-mSiO2 (Ni/hw-mSiO2) or commercial SiO2 (Ni/mSiO2) as supports. TPR and H2-chemisorption results revealed the existence of strong metal-interaction and more hydrogenation sites in Ni@hw-mSiO2. Therefore, Ni@hw-mSiO2 catalyst achieved an excellent catalytic activity and stability in the selective hydrogenation of quinoline into 1–4-tetrahydroquinoline (py-THQ), due to the more dispersed Ni species, strong metal-support interaction and confinement effect of porous silica shell.
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles encapsulated in hollow mesoporous silica spheres as an efficient catalyst for quinoline hydrogenation
